newsitem.title: GERMANY: German institute advocates EMU leeway for Italy.
newsitem.headline: German institute advocates EMU leeway for Italy.

text.p: Italy will probably fail to meet the fiscal targets to join European monetary union (EMU) at the start, but it should be given the same interpretive leeway as other countries, the German Institute for Economic Research (DIW) said on Wednesday.
Ultimately, the decision on whether to admit Italy, which has been making massive budgetary reforms, will be a political and not an economic one, DIW said.
While France and Germany, widely seen as the indispensible cornerstones of EMU, are having increasing difficulty in meeting the fiscal targets, Italy has been showing great progress, DIW said.
"The development in Italy shows how problematic it is to lay down precise criteria, which have no economic justification," DIW wrote.
"Italy has done a lot. The Maastricht Treaty's room for interpretation should be applied to Italy as to others."
Italy is likely to overshoot the EMU deficit target of three percent of gross domestic product, but it plans to slash its 1997 budget deficit by 62.5 trillion lire.
DIW estimated Italy's 1997 deficit at four percent of GDP, and called the European Commission's estimate of 3.3 percent "too optimistic."
The European Union will decide in 1998 which of the bloc's 15 members will be allowed into the circle of countries switching over to a single currency in 1999.

Italy is pinning its hopes of narrowing its budget-to-GDP gap on the massive budget cuts and a swift fall in interest rates. Lower rates would cut the cost of servicing Italy's mountain of debt -- a major component of the deficit.
The lira on Monday returned after a four year absence to the European Exchange Rate Mechanism, a development expected to enable rates to fall by stabilising the lira.
Germany has consistently argued against a softening of the Maastricht criteria to allow countries like Italy and Spain join EMU.
